newsitem.title: USA: US Commerce official sees momentum in Q4 GDP data.
newsitem.headline: US Commerce official sees momentum in Q4 GDP data.

text.p: A senior U.S. Commerce Department official on Friday said he saw momentum in this morning's report on fourth-quarter gross domestic product.

During an interview with Reuters Financial Television, U.S. Commerce Undersecretary Everett Ehrlich said the data showed the economy growing "substantially" in the last three months of 1996, "but I also think there's reason to see momentum for 1997."
The Commerce Department earlier reported that U.S. GDP grew by 4.7 percent in the fourth quarter, a sharp pickup from the 2.1 percent pace of the third quarter.
He cited his expectation for continued strong consumer spending as one reason he believed the economy would maintain its momentum in the first half of this year.
Asked whether one-time occurrences were at play in producing the surprisingly strong growth, Ehrlich said those were not a big factor.
"There's very little in the data that has to do with special factors," he said.
The most conspicuous special factor was the late harvest, which meant farm inventories were accumulated later in the year than normal.

The fourth-quarter GDP figure reported on Friday was the department's initial, or "advance," estimate of growth, which will be revised when reports, such as the trade and inventory data for December, become available.
Asked whether those would cause a downward revision to GDP, Ehrlich said that was unlikely as his department made conservative assumptions about the two items.
"I don't think we're going to see a downward revision surprise when we get export and inventory data for the month of December," he said.
On the subject of whether the strength of the dollar will dampen exports, thus exerting a restraining influence on growth, the Commerce official played down the potential for that.

"Of course, a rising dollar at some point is going to have some feedback for U.S. exports but the underlying competitiveness of U.S. production is so sound (and) investment has been so strong," Ehrlich said.

He also pointed to some positive effects of the strong dollar on the economy: "It helps contain inflation and it helps keep interest rates down in the final analysis and that's good throughout the economy."
Regarding inflation, Ehrlich was upbeat, predicting more good price behavior in future quarters.
